Organs/Tissues: Endothelial monolayer under controlled shear flow
Physiological/Pathological: Artery or venous-like shear conditions, modeling leukocyte rolling/adhesion in inflammation
Cell Source: Primary human endothelial cells (HUVEC or microvascular) or lines, plus perfused immune cells
Multiple Cell Types: Yes if including circulating leukocytes; endothelium forms 2D barrier
Stromal Cells: No (usually not included in standard assay)
Extracellular Matrix: Endothelium adheres to channel coating (e.g. collagen, fibronectin)
3D Scaffold: No, 2D cell monolayer on channel surface
Notable Features: Shear flow up to arterial rates, real-time imaging of rolling/adhesion, user-defined flow profiles
Plate/Format (Throughput): BioFlux plates: up to 24–48 channels per plate, medium throughput
Max Culture Duration: Hours–days for continuous flow assays (longer if carefully maintained)
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, microscopy of leukocyte-endothelium interactions, rolling velocities
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, from outlet wells for cytokines
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Possible, though limited yields from channel scraping
Readouts - Whole Tissue: In situ staining/imaging of the monolayer, no bulk tissue
Readouts - TEER: No integrated electrodes, typically measure function by morphological endpoints
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No built-in, rely on imaging metrics
Dead Volume: Low microfluidic channel volume (~100–200 µL total)
Perfused: Yes, pneumatic or pump-driven flow at controlled shear
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator or on-stage warming with optional dual gas input
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate, solution switching, drug or cell bolus introduction in real time

Model: BioFlux Thrombosis Model (Platelet Aggregation Under Flow)
Organs/Tissues: Simulated injured vessel surface + flowing whole blood
Physiological/Pathological: Studies platelet adhesion, activation, clot formation under shear (thrombosis)
Cell Source: Human blood (fresh or anticoagulated), channel coated with collagen or TF
Multiple Cell Types: Platelets + WBCs in blood; no tissue co-culture
Circulating Immune: Yes (WBCs in the blood sample), though focus is on platelets
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): No, single flow channel simulating vascular injury
Extracellular Matrix: Coated channel surfaces mimic subendothelial matrix (collagen, vWF)
Notable Features: Real-time platelet aggregation imaging under physiologic shear rates, drug testing (aspirin, etc.)
Max Culture Duration: Typically short (minutes–hours) as blood is perfused
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, measure platelet adhesion, clot size in real-time
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Possible but less common, usually end readout is imaging-based
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Potentially limited, can flush out RBCs/WBCs post-clot
Readouts - Whole Tissue: N/A, no tissue, just clot on channel
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No built-in, rely on optical imaging quantification
Perfused: Yes, controlling shear up to arterial levels
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator or stage-top environment, minimal O₂/CO₂ needs
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rates, drug addition, pulsatile or steady flow
model_availability: Commercial product (BioFlux), standard assay for thrombosis

Organs/Tissues: Mammalian cell layer (e.g. oral epithelium) + microbial biofilms under flow
Physiological/Pathological: Pathological infection or biofilm formation (oral, lung, device surfaces)
Cell Source: Host cells (epithelial or fibroblast lines) + microbes (bacteria/fungi), plus relevant media (saliva, etc.)
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (multi-species microbes + host cells), not typically adding immune cells
Stromal Cells: No (usually epithelial host only), or co-culture if desired
Circulating Immune: No, unless user flows immune cells in a custom approach
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Between host cells and microbes; single-channel design
Air-Liquid Interface: No, microbes in fluid flow, though partial bridging if simulating mucus on epithelium
Extracellular Matrix: Host cell monolayer or microbe-secreted biofilm matrix in situ
3D Scaffold: Biofilms self-assemble in 3D, not a pre-fabricated scaffold
Notable Features: Grow multi-species biofilm on real host cell surface under shear, test antibiotics or antiseptics
Plate/Format (Throughput): BioFlux plates (up to 24–48 channels), moderate throughput
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, direct microscopy of biofilm development (fluorescent labeling, viability stains)
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes (collect effluent to measure bacterial load, pH, secreted factors)
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, flush out biofilm or host cells for plating or sequencing
Readouts - Whole Tissue: In-chip staining or scraping for ex vivo analysis
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No built-in, rely on imaging and plating assays
Perfused: Yes, continuous flow of media or saliva across cell layer & microbes
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator or stage with optional dual gas for anaerobes or partial O₂
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow, media composition, antibiotics introduction, etc.
model_availability: Commercial product (BioFlux) used for infection/biofilm assays

Organs/Tissues: Not an organ model, but excitable cells (cardiomyocytes/neurons) in microfluidic patch-clamp system
Physiological/Pathological: Measures ion channel function, e.g. hERG cardiotoxicity, neuronal excitability
Cell Source: iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes, neuronal cell lines, or stable cell lines expressing ion channels
Multiple Cell Types: No, typically single cell type expressing channel of interest
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): No, each well is a patch-clamp site for channel recording
Air-Liquid Interface: No, cells in solution for patch clamp
Extracellular Matrix: Minimal; cells can be lightly adherent or in suspension
3D Scaffold: No, single-cell or small cluster approach
Notable Features: High-throughput automated voltage clamp recordings for drug-channel interactions, replaces manual patch clamp
Plate/Format (Throughput): 96- or 384-well IonFlux microfluidic plates, higher throughput for electrophysiology
Max Culture Duration: Hours for stable recordings, medium-term cell viability in plate
Readouts - Live Imaging: No; main readout is electrical current traces (patch clamp data)
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Rarely done, main readout is ionic currents
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Not typically (cells often lost after patching)
Readouts - MEA: Not an MEA approach, but direct patch clamp channels
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Yes, integrated microfluidic patch clamp electrodes for electrical signals
Dead Volume: Low in microfluidic cartridge, fast solution exchange for dose responses
Perfused: Yes, microfluidic flow of test compounds for rapid solution changes
Gas Mix Controlled: Usually standard incubator or ambient for short runs
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, software controls solution exchange, voltage protocols in real time
